ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We met a few times as a whole group at the beginning and end of the semester. Then we met in small mentor groups for the rest of the semester.
Weekly meetings with secondary advisor groups.
The course entailed independent student research facilitated by weekly meetings within mentor groups and with a thesis advisor.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We are assigned different milestones in order to help us make progress towards our senior essay (20 pages at the end of the semester for 2-term essayists, finals draft for 1-term students). I learned how to present the key frameworks of my thesis in an accessible way and found support in a weekly community and related assignments. By the end of the semester, I felt comfortable knowing where I was with my thesis and what I needed to do next semester in order to finish.
A deeper understanding of research methods and ways to write a good paper.

I conducted original research for my senior thesis, and learned a lot about the academic writing process. The thesis was a great opportunity to explore environmental issues that are of interest to me.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was difficult to balance both writing, researching, and the smaller weekly assignments. For example, I didn't use many of the sources I mentioned in my initial literature review. I wish there were more writing milestones instead of the other assignments. I think having a midpoint (10 pages by Thanksgiving break) or smaller writing milestones in between could be really helpful for students. Our mentors advised us to keep writing small chunks throughout the semester, but it was difficult to find that time in addition to the other assignments and responsibilities we have. I think that providing more structured writing goals could really help students especially during the last push of finals seasons. I loved the small group format and appreciate how friendly and supportive my fellow students were. It was also nice to hear everyone's projects at the end of the semester. Lastly, I think the initial presentations were a bit intimidating (esp. for week 1) and think that a midpoint presentation might give students more time to structure their thesis topic.
I really enjoyed meeting within the mentor groups each week. It was helpful to talk through problems and identify solutions with some of my EVST peers.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Flexible small group time meetings based on the needs to the people in the group. Good virtual engagement! Maybe some ideas for helping students connect outside of scheduled class times, connecting students who are working on similar topics. Prof. Park did a great job with reminders and being clear about assignments and expectations. The fact that there were so many professors was also an amazing experience and I am so grateful for the engagement of all of the EVST senior colloquium professors.
I thought that the course transitioned well to the Zoom format, particularly given the independent research aspect of the course. The mentor group really worked well over Zoom.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, a requirement for EVST seniors!

I would recommend this course to any prospective EVST student who is interested in conducting their own research. It is exciting to contribute to the existing body of literature in the environmental arena, and I hope to continue environmental research once again in the future.
